name: Progressive Facial Hemiatrophy (Parry-Romberg Syndrome)
chief_complaint: My face is shrinking unevenly and I have severe pain on one side
physical_findings: Sharply demarcated facial atrophy (coup de sabre appearance)
Bone and cartilage involvement in advanced cases
prognosis: Variable; progression typically stabilizes after 2-10 years but existing damage is permanent
description: A rare neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by progressive atrophy of skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle and sometimes bone, typically affecting one side of the face. The condition often begins in childhood or adolescence with unknown etiology, though autoimmune mechanisms are suspected. The atrophy progresses slowly before spontaneously arresting, leaving significant facial asymmetry.
risk_factors: History of trauma or infection (possible triggers)
